topic.title: ZeroNet traffic explanation
topic.body: Where is there an explanation of what traffic is run over clearnet when 'Tor Always' is *not* selected.

topic.title: ZeroID error: List index out of range
topic.body: Does anyone know what that error means?

topic.title: How do you rate limit ZeroNet?
topic.body:
I don't want my ISP to put me on a watch list for pushing the limit on bandwidth. Just today I seeded about 7Gb of data. My system is headless and runs 24/7, so it is easy for me to have considerable data flow rates.

I didn't see any options that I could uses to limit the throughput, so what are other people using to rate limit?

topic.title: Just a heads-up on Python 2.7
topic.body:
Python 2.7 will not be maintained past 2020... that is all.

https://pythonclock.org/

topic.title: If you're not using relative links on your ZeroNet site, then you're doing it wrong.
topic.body: Please don't hard code "http://127.0.0.1..." into links, because not everyone runs ZeroNet on the local machine. It seems that sites like ZeroTalk does It right, but many others don't.

Breaking things is fun.The spam will probably stop when I get too bored, or my script breaks, or someone implements a security measure, or my computer gets too slow from multiple instances eating up the RAM.Either way, decentralized shit almost never works, I will be really impressed if this network survives without using any centralized service like the ID providers.btw, the ID provider idea is pretty good, I don't think I can generate IDs fast enough to do any real harm, but using them is kinda against the decentralization thing right? :^)

1565430707_16joHUdKRd7Qfjp6fjTfHkaqwkrUh.body:
> [r6uysrgw4g4tg](#comment_7_1DJDoGruBajCdDVznWRKd2MBLZZUYpM8EJ): What does that have to do with anything...? Gab is full on Zionist and is happy to host literal ADL drones that hunt down, harass, attempt to dox, and attempt to deplatform so-called antisemites. "The Catcher" comes to mind. They also deplatformed Patrick Little after shadow-banning proved futile.

I've been on Gab from the beginning and have seen this same bullshit lie plastered on Voat, Reddit and other sites. Patrick Little was banned for doxing which is against Gab rules. He was given many chances to redeem himself but continued anyway. Stop spreading bullshit lies about other sites unless you can provide definitive proof... otherwise you're just the Jew shill trying to undermine sites that support free speech.

> [r6uysrgw4g4tg](#comment_9_1DJDoGruBajCdDVznWRKd2MBLZZUYpM8EJ): It's been over five hours.  Cough up the proof of dox if he's really guilty. Every time this stupid subject gets brought up, no one can ever produce the proof of the accusation... [...]

There have been several high profile banns on Gab. I believe the first was Weev because he made a post about killing Jew children which approached the call to action line.

Then there was Paul Nehlen who was banned for doxing (https://forward.com/fast-forward/398249/even-the-alt-right-is-sick-of-paul-nehlen).

Then there was Patrick Little who pushed the envelope with posts against Jews, where some were very close to the call to action line. The post on doxing was removed before anyone saw it, and while many requested to see it, it was never released... because that would be doxxing.

Many of the posts are posted on Patrick Little's site (https://littlerevolution.us/2018/11/20/banned-from-gab/).

It's kinda funny that you demand proof from me, yet you have no proof of the ban otherwise.

1566241934_13ifSHXbs2RtyHF4qkn4GrJ3krWEA.body:
It's funny how *Security Concerned* people willingly trust a VPN service: https://gist.github.com/joepie91/5a9909939e6ce7d09e29

Kinda weird, don't you think?

> [r3naam3r](#comment_25_1Dssbq2y2JDD14aojGG9RX3d5EPpw6zQxM): So find me a better alternative for system-wide secure connection. VPNs at least protect me from ISP spying, protect me from copyright scareletters, and allow me to bypass geoblock. They are definitely better than using clear connection. I'd rather some privacy-friendly country VPN have my logs who may not sell them to admakers than my ISP who will DEFINITELY sell them and keep them forever.

I don't have a problem with VPN's as long as people understand that they are not a security utopia.

1567130399_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qk.body:
> [gitcenter](#comment_817_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Well, uh, all traffic is run over clearnet in this case. Namely: [...]

I am running ZeroNet on A headless Debian box in "Tor:Available" mode (I browse on a windows machine). My understanding was that Tor is used for some of the traffic in this case, but I couldn't find an explanation of how ZeroNet determined when to use Tor and when not to.

My assumption was that in "Tor: Available" mode, file downloads are done through Tor and stuff like tracker communication is done outside Tor.

1566642594_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
What version of ZeroNet is required to install the plugin?

Edit: some comments here indicate that you need to be running a py3 version of ZeroNet... it might be a good idea to put that requirement next to the install button where everyone can see it.

> [gitcenter](#comment_839_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): It tells you that you have too old ZeroNet version when you try installing.

Why answer with something that is obvious, instead of telling people *what version is required* ????

> [gitcenter](#comment_842_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Hm, there's no button to "update to this version", there's only "update to latest version", so my answer is both straightforward and easy to follow.

I didn't ask about a button... why even bring that up. I only asked about the *minimum required version to use name.YO*.

> [gitcenter](#comment_848_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): When you press "Install", it either works or doesn't work. If it installs successfully, you shouldn't even care about the version because you're running the correct one. And if it doesn't work, there isn't anything you can do except updating to the latest version.

This tells me that you don't know. If you did, you would just answer with a version number.

> [gitcenter](#comment_843_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): I've updated the message to either "Your ZeroNet is outdated, please reinstall from zeronet.io" or "Please update ZeroNet to (at least) v0.7.0, rev4191" if you think that's required.

This answer is at least close because it does have a version number.

>"Your ZeroNet is outdated, please reinstall from zeronet.io"

Yes, I know that, it's obvious from the error elicited when trying to install the plugin.

> [publicality](#comment_45_1BP5GrM5EDw9SVGmRJan1kvQ2DB2Xm1Rgo): Everysites, except for ZeroHello, even .bit and .yo are affected. I should've copied the error that appeared on screen... [...]

Don't bother asking him about versions and/or rev's required for Name.YO, because he won't tell you.

(read our exchange below for an example)

> [gitcenter](#comment_923_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): I told you the correct version and a rev, so I'm pretty sure that I answered your question

I was being facetious because I knew you would see this... you will have to admit that it would have been a lot easier if you had just told me the version/rev from the beginning. Name.YO must do some kind of check to see if ZeroNet is the correct version and if not it elicits the error to update ZeroNet. I could have looked at the code myself if I knew where it was, but I figured it would have been just as easy to ask.

> [filips](#comment_179_1LFu1BTScmY82HHtg3TY2jAuSrCYNsQWEY): @gitcenter @nofish I would also recommend to update ZeroUpdate zite with better text description. [...]

Why would you want to do proper version control?   /s

1568607154_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qk.body:
> [undisputed](#comment_1_19MNueeefmtMbBKPCdqtB8UnQmZC8QwLJX): QoS

Quality of Service... maybe some context would help explain whatever you are trying to convey here.

> [randomshits](#comment_114_1CuFETj5LtyEduzaoAcdv9sMAQtYRqjqDY): My ISP charges me an additional 20 on my bill if I go over 1 TB, so I just use 5 of that and put zeronet on a vps that comes with 100gb of bandwidth a month.

I actually have a business class account and have exceeded 2TB per month many times. I'm just a little concerned about Zeronet being open ended as far as bandwidth goes. It seems that the usage isn't consistent like Freenet is and I may get dog piled if the leachers proliferate suddenly.

On Freenet I can set an upper limit and not worry about it. QoS is not the best because it doesn't understand the protocol to the degree that it can optimize bursting on small packets and limiting where the larger data lies... this can only be done in the application.

1574717925_14dsVvztuXjBxWmk4s4HjUnxuN4Ae.body:
I hate all of this stupid "sudo" shit... just login as root and do the work. I've administered Unix systems from the late 70's and never trashed a system. Telling someone to edit using 'sed' is a sure way to totally trash a system with one typo on the command line.

Most Debian based systems provide 'nano' for a simple text editor... just learn to use it.

1574608682_1CYE9ryvvXCW4CJPX51T24BFD62cy.body:
> [goodafternoon](#comment_54_1BL1pFELvZ58apCLcxogy2W66aC4vKLfY3): I wish Zites here had auto content deletion after a set date.

That's kinda the way Freenet works. If content isn't accessed for a period of time, it will cease to exist on the network. That prevents stale crap from accumulating and eating up disk space.

> [goodafternoon](#comment_56_1BL1pFELvZ58apCLcxogy2W66aC4vKLfY3): there was some things I need to buy to use the network?

You don't have to buy anything, you just download it and run it: [Freenet](https://freenetproject.org/)
